awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: From Brains to Society: Neural Underpinnings of Collective Behaviors Via Massive Data and Experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite thousands of investigations on the neural basis of individual behaviors and even more studies on collective behaviors, a clear bridge between the organization of individual brains and their combinational impact on group behaviors, such as cooperation and conflict and ultimately collective action, is lacking. To address the grand challenge of inferring group cooperation from the functional neuroarchitecture of individual brains, this project will harness advances in data, experiment and computation. Specifically, it will integrate, for the first time, existing large-scale human functional neuroimaging data, prospectively collected individual and group behavioral data from a large cohort, with cutting-edge machine learning tools, hierarchical models and large-scale simulations. This is a collaborative effort between a team of neuroscientists, social scientists and data scientists, that aims to elucidate the neural basis of cooperation, a fundamental process in a functioning society and at the core of social environments. 

The project will first harness the combined wealth of existing neuroimaging and behavioral data from large-scale studies, including the Human Connectome-Lifespan (HCP-L) and the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) and will leverage recent breakthroughs in machine learning to characterize the diversity, individuality and commonality of neural circuits (the connectome) supporting cognitive function across the lifespan. It will then conduct large-scale (~10,000 individuals) online behavioral experiments to identify connections between individual behaviors, decisions and group behaviors during a Public Goods Game. The experiments will measure individual proclivity towards cooperation and the social welfare obtained by cooperation, leading to potentially transformative insights into the emergence of cooperation within groups via individual behaviors. The resulting first-of-its-kind dataset may become a very valuable resource to the research community. Large-scale simulations based on statistical models estimated from this and the assembled neuroimaging datasets will then assess the direct or indirect relationships between individual connectomes and cooperation in group settings, and will elucidate the role of group processes in amplifying or ameliorating individual differences towards collective outcomes. Findings from this project may have a transformative impact on the scientific community's currently incomplete understanding of how individual brains shape societal behavior via cognitive, social, and interactive mechanisms.

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution (HDR) Big Idea activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Each individual’s unique brain wiring pattern - their connectome - is shaped by a multitude of genetic, environmental and experiential factors across the lifespan, but most significantly during the development. The connectome supports individual and collective behaviors, but mappings relationships between the diversity of its wiring and that of behaviors contributing to collective actions, like cooperation, remain unclear. The overarching goal of this cross-disciplinary project was to elucidate the organization (wiring) of brain circuits that play a central role in collective behaviors. It specifically focused on adolescence, a sensitive developmental period characterized by significant evolution in social function, including prosocial and cooperative behaviors. To achieve this goal the project leveraged big data from large-scale studies, primarily the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) study, a nationwide longitudinal investigation of brain development in over 10,000 youth from pre/early adolescence to young adulthood. Using cutting-edge analytic tools, it systematically characterized developing neural circuits crucial for cooperative behaviors in a cohort or over 5,000 youth, and assessed the impact of environmental, physiological and other individual factors on their organization. Through collaborative research with data scientists, the project also investigated fundamental mechanisms underlying brain’s ability to rapidly process information from the outside world, respond to cognitive demands, switch between tasks, and learn.


This project has led to multiple scientific discoveries on the development of brain circuits that support collective behaviors and the multitude of factors that shape them. Findings have shown that these circuits are vulnerable to extensive risk factors, including inadequate sleep, excess BMI, rigid parental beliefs and behaviors, and negative relationships with family members, teachers and peers, have negative effects on the wiring of these brain circuits and the behaviors they support. In contrast, regular physical activity, positive parenting and affection towards the youth, a cohesive family environment, good relationships with teachers and an enriching classroom environment, and positive peer relationships, including having close friends, have neuroprotective effects on these brain circuits and support the development of prosocial behaviors.

On a mechanistic level, this project has also made significant discoveries on how the organization of brain circuits plays a critical role in controlling the brain’s ability to rapidly respond to external stimuli and cognitive demands. The brain is a dynamic system that changes the configuration of its functional wiring as a function of time. The underlying mechanisms underlying this capacity are not well understood at the level of large circuits in the human brain. Assuming a novel control framework to investigate this capacity, the project has shown that a small set of select brain areas that extensively communicate with the rest of the brain play critical roles in controlling the brain’s ability to vary over time and coordinate its activity in response to cognitive demands.

Finally, the project has generated novel compute infrastructure, and a platform for large-scale investigations of brain circuits using multimodal neuroimaging data, and comprehensive signal, image, and network analytic tools. This platform has been shared with the broader scientific community and may become a valuable resource in future research.
